title: Harry Belafonte - To Wish You A Merry Christmas (1958)@flac
description:
When Harry Belafonte, born March 1, 1927 in Harlem, New York, spent some of his early years in Jamaica, he not only brought the traditional calypso music of the islands to Pop prominence with his late 1952 rendition of Scarlet Ribbons (For Her Hair), which ended up at # 30 on the Pop charts on RCA Victor 5051, he would carry that genre right into the dawning era of R&R, and to 1957 would add 11 more such hits (he would add two more non-calypso hits in 1967/68 that made the Adult Contemporary charts) - all with RCA Victor. He would also see six of his albums go Gold from 1956 to 1961.

Along the way he was backed by some of the finest such orchestras of the period, including those of Millard Thomas, Henri Rene, Hugo Winterhalter, William Lorin, Tony Scott and Bob Corman. It was, in fact, Corman with his orchestra and chorus who backed him on his first Christmas album which initially came out in 1958 as RCA Victor 1887 with a quite different red sleeve cover.

When a vinyl re-release came out in 1962 as RCA Victor 2626, and with the same cover seen here, it contained the original tracks, although the side 2 order was changed with the addition of the bonus track, Mary's Boy Child. Featured in Where The Little Jesus Sleeps and Mary, Mary are the guitars of Laurindo Almeida and Millard Thomas.

The decision to include Mary's Boy Child in 1962 was in response to popular demand, as it had been a # 12 Billboard Top 10 hit in 1956 on RCA Victor 47-6735 with the backing of the Lorin orchestra and the guitars of Thomas and Frantz Casseus (the flip was the non-seasonal Venezuela). That revamped album reached # 125 on Billboard's Pop Album charts in 1962, then charted again on their Christmas charts in 1964 (# 34), 1966 (# 58), and 1967 (# 47). (Customer from Amazon)

 
http://i.imgur.com/qLD988m.jpg
